Problem:
Let us analyze a control system represented by the equation \\( \\dot{x} = Mx + Nu \\) where \\( M \\) and \\( N \\) are constant matrices, and \\( u \\) is an input signal. We consider the implications of applying a Laplace transform to the system, defined as \\( L[x](s) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st} x(t) dt \\), and then manipulating the input signal \\( u(t) \\).

If an intervention changes the input signal from \\( u(t) \\) to \\( v(t) \\) at a time \\( t_1 \\), will the Laplace transformed state \\( L[x](s) \\) for s > t_1 depend solely on the original system matrices M and N?
Explanation: The intervention changing \\( u(t) \\) to \\( v(t) \\) impacts the system's input, modifying the term \\( Nu \\) in the equation to \\( Nv. \\) Consequently, the resultant state \\( x(t) \\) and its Laplace transform \\( L[x](s) \\) will depend on both the characteristics of the new input \\( v(t) \\) and the matrices M and N.
